content.text: We created this template for your community. Below is a summary of the starting settings that come along with the
template. You can easily change the setup or further customize this space for your community by clicking and exploring
Every member that joins your space will receive the Default role. A default member will have:
Until changed by an Admin, a member with the Default role will be able to:
Create a proposal in any proposal category
Create a post in any forum category
Here are a couple of custom roles to get you started but feel free to create more or import from Discord, CollabLand, or Guild.
Assign this role to a member to help moderate your space. In addition to default permissions, a user with the Moderator role will be able to:
Moderate and access all Forum categories
The Core Contributor role is assigned as the Reviewer in all of the preset proposal templates.

You will start with these 6 forum categories:

children.title: Onboarding

content.text: Create an onboarding experience for your members. Customize the toggle lists below with your onboarding information.  Add a new toggle list by typing

Ethereum is a decentralized, open-source blockchain with smart contract functionality. The native cryptocurrency of the Ethereum blockchain is ether, often represented as ETH or using the symbol Ξ. ETH is the second largest cryptocurrency by market capitalization, second only to Bitcoin. I'm sure you already have lots of questions, so let's break it down.
A cryptocurrency is a new form of digital money powered by cryptography.

Bitcoin was the first cryptocurrency, it was revolutionary because it allowed anyone to send funds anywhere in the world without a middle man or centralized authority - meaning it was the first payment technology to directly connect sender and recipient, and allow users to hold their own funds in a way that nobody else can tell them how to use those funds. This is possible due to the utilization of blockchain technology, which originated with Bitcoin.

A blockchain is a database of transactions that is updated and shared across many computers in a network. A new set of transactions is added at periodic intervals, these groups of transactions are called 'blocks' and can only be added - data cannot be removed from the blockchain. Because no data can be removed and all transactions are visible to everyone on the network, blockchains enable a higher degree of trust between parties when transacting online.

Ethereum is programmable via smart contracts. Smart contracts are computer programs that are stored on the Ethereum blockchain and only execute when triggered by a transaction. Smart contracts enable decentralized applications, or dApps, to run on the network. So while Bitcoin is simply a payment network, Ethereum is a blossoming ecosystem of financial services, games, social networks, artists and collector communities, and more - all enabled by permissionless dApps.

NFT stands for Non-Fungible Token, another awesome feature that is enabled by Ethereum is tokens. There is a myriad of types of tokens, but NFTs are a special kind. Typical tokens utilize the ERC-20 standard and are considered fungible, meaning any token is exactly the same as any other token. For example, if we were trading $1,000 USD for 1 ETH, I wouldn't have a preference

ETH you give me as they are all indistinguishable from each other, just like any $100 bill is the same as any other $100 bill. But let's say we are trading $1,000 USD for Gnar 420. If you tried to trade me Gnar 69 instead, I would reject this because this is not what we agreed on. Gnar 69 and 420 are unique, distinguishable tokens with different properties - in other words, they are

"CC0 enables scientists, educators, artists and other creators and owners of copyright- or database-protected content to waive those interests in their works and hereby place them as completely as possible in the public domain, so that others may freely build upon, enhance and reuse the works for any purposes without restriction under copyright or database law.

In contrast to CC's license that allow copyright holders to choose from a range of permissions while retaining their copyright, CC0 empowers yet another choice altogether - the coice to opt out of copyright and database protection, and the exclusive rights automatically granted to creators - the "no rights reserved" alternative to our licenses."
-Description of the CC0 License from Creative Commons Website

The Creative Commons CC0 "No Rights Reserved" license was first released in 2007 but didn't get much attention until 2016. It essentially allows anyone to take a creator's work and do anything they want with it, because there are "no rights reserved". So you can use their art to make more art, to sell AR filters, or even custom sets of legos! You are free to do

There are many messaging and chat apps out there, but none are more popular among web3 communities and DAOs than Discord is. For a new user of Discord, joining a project's server can often be quite overwhelming. There can be dozens of categories with hundreds of channels being used to communicate by thousands of users every day, so having a general idea of how to operate within Discord is often helpful in preventing information overload when first getting started. Another thing to remember is that nothing beats experience, so while we will do our best to prepare you you'll still learn more from actually

The first thing you'll need to do is create an account and log in. Once you log in, you'll need to join servers to get in on the discussion. Below is a link that will take you directly to the DAO Discord server.

Now that you've made your way into a server, let's take a look at how to navigate the user interface and channels. First, you'll notice that the servers you've joined will be displayed along the left side of your screen. Servers can actually be grouped together into folders by dragging one server onto another one. Next, along the left side next to the servers list, you'll notice the list of categories with their associated channels below. Finally, you'll find several buttons near the search bar which control the sidebar on the right side of the screen.

Every discord server is different, but once you have spent time in a variety of them you will notice consistent patterns with the way they are organized. As shown in the example above, you can see that the categories located at the top of the channels list contain information and utilities. Often you'll find these types of channels grouped at the top of the channel list like this for convenient access. These channels will highlight relevant announcements and social updates, provide quick access to frequently asked questions and official links, and a channel for verifying your NFT holdings.

There are also different types of channels which can contain sub-channels: either threads or forum posts. The image below on the left depicts a thread within a standard channel. These threads contain focus discussion on certain topics. A list of all the created threads can be found by clicking the thread icon in the top right corner as highlighted in the large screenshot above. The image below on the right depicts a forum channel with the posts contained within it. While these are two different formats, they accomplish the same objective of providing a place for focused discussion.

Another feature you should be aware of are Events. Teams are able to schedule events within their Discord server that can link to a voice channel or external location such as Twitter Spaces. To bring up the Events window, click on the Events button beneath the server banner in the top left, like in the screenshot from the Lil Nouns server on the left below. This will bring up the menu, shown the right. Here you can RSVP by clicking the 'Interested' button so you will receive a notification when the event is scheduled to start. You can also obtain the link to send people directly to this event by clicking the 'Share' button.

Navigating discussions and operating within Discord gets much easier with time, but there is commonly an additional step required once you've joined a server to verify that you are a holder of a certain NFT and gain full access to the server. There are different apps that are commonly used among Discord servers to verify on-chain ownership: CollabLand, Guild, and Vulcan, just to name a few.

There are several different in-browser wallets you can use. The most popular are MetaMask and Rainbow. Below you'll find links to articles on each of the sites which introduce you to setting up your wallet, connecting to web3 enabled websites, and submitting transactions on-chain.
Be sure to write down a copy of your seed phrase when you create your wallet, this is the
way to recover your funds if something happens to your computer or browser. Take the security of your wallets seriously as mistakes do happen, and are often permanent.
Once you have a wallet installed and created, move ahead to learn about DAOs or skip straight to learning about how Nouns-style auctions work.

Think of them like an internet-native business that's collectively owned and managed by its members. They have built-in treasuries that no one has the authority to access without the approval of the group. Decisions are governed by proposals and voting to ensure everyone in the organization has a voice.

DAO stands for decentralized autonomous organization. In essence, it is a new type of organization that is enabled by blockchain technology. It allows people to organize themselves into communities that manage a treasury which can be utilized in any way the DAO desires. This is enabled in a trustless and transparent manner due to governance processes being encoded on-chain, but these processes are determined in a democratic way through voting instead of being set and enforced by a centralized entity.

Many types of DAOs have formed over the past several years. There are DAOs for collectors, artists, developers and designers, and more are emerging every day! No matter what your interests are there is a place for you to fit in. Just be sure to go in with an open mind, read as much as you can, and ask lots of questions.
Nouns is a generative non-fungible token project on the Ethereum blockchain. Nouns are 32x32 pixel characters based on people, places, and things. One Noun will be
generated every day, forever. Here are some examples of Nouns
One Noun is trustlessly auctioned every 24 hours, forever.
100% of Noun auction proceeds are trustlessly sent to the treasury.
Settlement of one auction kicks off the next.
All Nouns are members of Nouns DAO.
Nouns DAO uses a fork of
One Noun is equal to one vote.
The treasury is controlled exclusively by Nouns via governance.
Artwork is generative and stored directly on-chain (not IPFS).
No explicit rules exist for attribute scarcity; all Nouns are equally rare.
Nounders receive rewards in the form of Nouns (10% of supply for first 5 years).
One noun is auctioned every 24 hours, forever. One interface for participating in noun auctions is
, which is a website built and maintained by the project founders ('Nounders'):

In the auction above, Noun 8, which is the 9th Noun (Noun IDs start at 0) is for sale. The current bid is 88.88 ETH (Ether), and there are 2 hours, 21 minutes, and 50 seconds remaining in the auction. If this auction ends with no further bids, 88.88 ETH from xaix.eth ($286,824 USD as of this writing) will be automatically and trustlessly sent to the Nouns DAO Treasury and xaix.eth will win this Noun, which means that the ERC-721 token will be transferred to their address.
You can see all the Noun ERC-721 tokens here:
Because of the way Ethereum works, Noun auctions must be settled after they are completed. The auction settlement transaction does three things:
1. Sends the current NOUN ERC-721 token to the winner of the auction
3. Begins the next 24 hour Noun auction.
This means that if you win the auction you will
receive your NFT until the auction is settled!

The description above outlines how the original Nouns auction works, but many newer DAOs have forked the auction mechanics and altered the variables. Some have a much faster auction cadence, like Lil Nouns which has an auction every 15 minutes! Wizards DAO has experimented with auctioning up to 5 Wizards at a single time, and Gnars DAO has implemented the Gnarving which is effectively similar to a Bitcoin halvening event and results in one Gnar, less often, forever.
-What happens to my ETH if someone outbids me?
When a bid is received that is higher than the current highest bid, the ETH for your bid will be automatically returned to your wallet.
-The auction says I won, how do I receive my NFT?

Once an auction has completed, an additional transaction is required to 'settle' the auction. Settling the auction releases the previous NFT to the winner, mints a new NFT, and starts the next auction.
-Why did the timer extend at the last second?
When a new high bid is received within the last 2 minutes the auction timer is extended for an additional 2 minutes. This will repeat until no new bid is received in the last 2 minutes.
Anybody can settle any auction, it does not have to be the winner who settles.
Yes, settling requires submitting a transaction to the Ethereum blockchain therefore there gas fees associated with submitting this transaction.
Anybody can settle any auction, it does not have to be the winner who settles.
-If I didn't win the auction but I settle, can I take that NFT?
No, only the highest bidder prior to the end of the auction can receive that NFT.
-I really liked that NFT but it didn't receive any bids and was burned, can I pay to obtain it?
No, once an NFT is burned it is burned forever. There is no way to retrieve an NFT from the burn address.

First off, what is governance? Governance in the context of DAOs includes the processes for coordination among members - how proposals are brought to the attention of the DAO, how proposals are then moved into and through different funding processes, how the DAO collectively votes on actions to take moving forward, etc. Each DAO will have a unique governance process depending on their needs and use case, but the overall concept of raising awareness of a proposal, bringing it to the community for feedback, and submitting on-chain is similar across the ecosystem.

, which is an off-chain governance platform. Snapshot allows for governance decisions to be voted on off-chain but trigger on-chain actions. This saves members gas money while voting, but does have some limitations.

In general, governance can be boiled down to members submitting and voting on proposals. But within the DAO we have organizational structures in place to allow members to focus on the things they do best and coordinate as teams, rather than everyone working on their own and trying to coordinate with everyone else. We call these structures "Pods" and are essentially just teams that focus their efforts on certain aspects of the DAO's operations. This allows for more efficient management and distribution of work.
The beauty of decentralization is that not everybody has to perfectly agree for a group to come to consensus about a topic. The term 'Nounish' is frequently used across the nouniverse, but what
does it mean? Below are a couple takes on what 'Nounish' means from a Nounder and prominent Nouner.

Even though these are just the opinions of a couple well known community members, the general sentiment is that nounish things are fun, creative, positive, weird, and often educational. Being 'nounish' means going out and doing helpful or creative things, contributing to the community in the best way you can.

Servers can actually be grouped together into folders by dragging one server onto another one. Next, along the left side next to the servers list, you'll notice the list of categories with their associated channels below. Finally, you'll find several buttons near the search bar which control the sidebar on the right side of the screen.Every discord server is different, but once you have spent time in a variety of them you will notice consistent patterns with the way they are organized. As shown in the example above, you can see that the categories located at the top of the channels list contain information and utilities. Often you'll find these types of channels grouped at the top of the channel list like this for convenient access. These channels will highlight relevant announcements and social updates, provide quick access to frequently asked questions and official links, and a channel for verifying your NFT holdings.There are also different types of channels which can contain sub-channels: either threads or forum posts. The image below on the left depicts a thread within a standard channel. These threads contain focus discussion on certain topics. A list of all the created threads can be found by clicking the thread icon in the top right corner as highlighted in the large screenshot above. The image below on the right depicts a forum channel with the posts contained within it. While these are two different formats, they accomplish the same objective of providing a place for focused discussion.Another feature you should be aware of are Events. Teams are able to schedule events within their Discord server that can link to a voice channel or external location such as Twitter Spaces. To bring up the Events window, click on the Events button beneath the server banner in the top left, like in the screenshot from the Lil Nouns server on the left below. This will bring up the menu, shown the right. Here you can RSVP by clicking the 'Interested' button so you will receive a notification when the event is scheduled to start. You can also obtain the link to send people directly to this event by clicking the 'Share' button.Navigating discussions and operating within Discord gets much easier with time, but there is commonly an additional step required once you've joined a server to verify that you are a holder of a certain NFT and gain full access to the server. There are different apps that are commonly used among Discord servers to verify on-chain ownership: CollabLand, Guild, and Vulcan, just to name a few. Get Started with a WalletThere are several different in-browser wallets you can use. The most popular are MetaMask and Rainbow. Below you'll find links to articles on each of the sites which introduce you to setting up your wallet, connecting to web3 enabled websites, and submitting transactions on-chain.Be sure to write down a copy of your seed phrase when you create your wallet, this is the only way to recover your funds if something happens to your computer or browser. Take the security of your wallets seriously as mistakes do happen, and are often permanent.Once you have a wallet installed and created, move ahead to learn about DAOs or skip straight to learning about how Nouns-style auctions work.What is a DAO?Think of them like an internet-native business that's collectively owned and managed by its members. They have built-in treasuries that no one has the authority to access without the approval of the group. Decisions are governed by proposals and voting to ensure everyone in the organization has a voice.-Description of a DAO from Ethereum.orgDAO stands for decentralized autonomous organization. In essence, it is a new type of organization that is enabled by blockchain technology. It allows people to organize themselves into communities that manage a treasury which can be utilized in any way the DAO desires. This is enabled in a trustless and transparent manner due to governance processes being encoded on-chain, but these processes are determined in a democratic way through voting instead of being set and enforced by a centralized entity.Many types of DAOs have formed over the past several years. There are DAOs for collectors, artists, developers and designers, and more are emerging every day! No matter what your interests are there is a place for you to fit in. Just be sure to go in with an open mind, read as much as you can, and ask lots of questions.What are Nouns?Nouns is a generative non-fungible token project on the Ethereum blockchain. Nouns are 32x32 pixel characters based on people, places, and things. One Noun will be generated every day, forever. Here are some examples of NounsSummaryNouns artwork is in the public domain.One Noun is trustlessly auctioned every 24 hours, forever.100% of Noun auction proceeds are trustlessly sent to the treasury.Settlement of one auction kicks off the next.All Nouns are members of Nouns DAO.Nouns DAO uses a fork of Compound Governance.One Noun is equal to one vote.The treasury is controlled exclusively by Nouns via governance.Artwork is generative and stored directly on-chain (not IPFS).No explicit rules exist for attribute scarcity; all Nouns are equally rare.Nounders receive rewards in the form of Nouns (10% of supply for first 5 years).How do Nounish Auctions Work?One noun is auctioned every 24 hours, forever. One interface for participating in noun auctions is nouns.wtf, which is a website built and maintained by the project founders ('Nounders'):In the auction above, Noun 8, which is the 9th Noun (Noun IDs start at 0) is for sale. The current bid is 88.88 ETH (Ether), and there are 2 hours, 21 minutes, and 50 seconds remaining in the auction. If this auction ends with no further bids, 88.88 ETH from xaix.eth ($286,824 USD as of this writing) will be automatically and trustlessly sent to the Nouns DAO Treasury and xaix.eth will win this Noun, which means that the ERC-721 token will be transferred to their address. You can see all the Noun ERC-721 tokens here: https://opensea.io/collection/nounsAuction SettlementBecause of the way Ethereum works, Noun auctions must be settled after they are completed. The auction settlement transaction does three things:1. Sends the current NOUN ERC-721 token to the winner of the auction2. Generates the next Noun3. Begins the next 24 hour Noun auction.This means that if you win the auction you will not receive your NFT until the auction is settled!Nounish AuctionsThe description above outlines how the original Nouns auction works, but many newer DAOs have forked the auction mechanics and altered the variables. Some have a much faster auction cadence, like Lil Nouns which has an auction every 15 minutes! Wizards DAO has experimented with auctioning up to 5 Wizards at a single time, and Gnars DAO has implemented the Gnarving which is effectively similar to a Bitcoin halvening event and results in one Gnar, less often, forever.Frequently Asked Questions-What happens to my ETH if someone outbids me?When a bid is received that is higher than the current highest bid, the ETH for your bid will be automatically returned to your wallet.-The auction says I won, how do I receive my NFT?Once an auction has completed, an additional transaction is required to 'settle' the auction. Settling the auction releases the previous NFT to the winner, mints a new NFT, and starts the next auction.-Why did the timer extend at the last second?When a new high bid is received within the last 2 minutes the auction timer is extended for an additional 2 minutes. This will repeat until no new bid is received in the last 2 minutes.-Who can settle?Anybody can settle any auction, it does not have to be the winner who settles.-Does it cost money to settle?Yes, settling requires submitting a transaction to the Ethereum blockchain therefore there gas fees associated with submitting this transaction.-Who can settle?Anybody can settle any auction, it does not have to be the winner who settles.-If I didn't win the auction but I settle, can I take that NFT?No, only the highest bidder prior to the end of the auction can receive that NFT.-I really liked that NFT but it didn't receive any bids and was burned, can I pay to obtain it?No, once an NFT is burned it is burned forever. There is no way to retrieve an NFT from the burn address.How does Governance Work?First off, what is governance? Governance in the context of DAOs includes the processes for coordination among members - how proposals are brought to the attention of the DAO, how proposals are then moved into and through different funding processes, how the DAO collectively votes on actions to take moving forward, etc. Each DAO will have a unique governance process depending on their needs and use case, but the overall concept of raising awareness of a proposal, bringing it to the community for feedback, and submitting on-chain is similar across the ecosystem.Gnars DAO currently utilizes Snapshot governance, which is an off-chain governance platform. Snapshot allows for governance decisions to be voted on off-chain but trigger on-chain actions. This saves members gas money while voting, but does have some limitations.In general, governance can be boiled down to members submitting and voting on proposals. But within the DAO we have organizational structures in place to allow members to focus on the things they do best and coordinate as teams, rather than everyone working on their own and trying to coordinate with everyone else. We call these structures "Pods" and are essentially just teams that focus their efforts on certain aspects of the DAO's operations. This allows for more efficient management and distribution of work.What is ‘Nounish’?The beauty of decentralization is that not everybody has to perfectly agree for a group to come to consensus about a topic. The term 'Nounish' is frequently used across the nouniverse, but what exactly does it mean? Below are a couple takes on what 'Nounish' means from a Nounder and prominent Nouner.Even though these are just the opinions of a couple well known community members, the general sentiment is that nounish things are fun, creative, positive, weird, and often educational. Being 'nounish' means going out and doing helpful or creative things, contributing to the community in the best way you can.Our DAOMissionQuisque nec vehicula libero, nec aliquet sapien. children.title: Community Moderation

content.text: As a moderator on the Gnars DAO server, it is your responsibility to help create and maintain a welcoming, respectful, and productive community. To do this, you should follow these guidelines:
Be respectful and professional: Treat others with kindness and respect, and avoid using offensive language or behavior. Remember that your words and actions reflect on the entire community.
Encourage discussion and collaboration: Help foster a sense of community by encouraging open and respectful dialogue, and by promoting collaboration and cooperation.
Maintain order: Keep an eye on the server and take action as needed to maintain order and prevent conflicts. This may include moderating chats, enforcing rules, and taking other appropriate actions.
Stay up to date: Stay informed about the latest developments and activities on the server by reading announcements and participating in discussions.
As a moderator, you may occasionally need to create new rooms or threads on the Gnars DAO server. To do this, follow these steps:

Determine the purpose of the room or thread: Before you create a new room or thread, think carefully about what it will be used for. Is it intended for a specific topic or activity? Who will use it? (If created don forget to add the purpose in the room description)
Choose the appropriate type of room or thread: Based on the purpose of the room or thread, decide whether it should be a text channel, voice channel, or a thread in an existing text channel.
Name the room or thread: Choose a descriptive and appropriate name for the room or thread. Avoid using vague or misleading names.

Set permissions and rules: If necessary, set permissions and rules for the room or thread to ensure that it is used in an appropriate manner. For example, you may want to restrict access to certain users or require that users follow certain guidelines when participating.
Here is a template to copy and paste before creating a new room/thread

```yml

ROOM REQUEST

Purpose: Example 
Type: //room or thread
Name: //include emoji
Permission Details: 

```
After posting, ping other moderators in #moderation room in Discord and wait for then to vote with 👍🏻 or 👎🏻
Recommendations for When to Create a Thread or a Room

Use threads for specific discussions: If you want to start a discussion on a specific topic within an existing text channel, consider creating a thread. This will keep the discussion separate from the rest of the channel and make it easier for users to follow.

Use rooms for long-term or ongoing discussions: If you want to create a space for an ongoing discussion or activity, consider creating a separate room. This will allow users to easily find and participate in the discussion or activity whenever they want.
I hope this handbook is helpful as you perform your duties as a moderator on the Gnars DAO server. If you have any further questions or concerns, don't hesitate to ask.

pages.title: Grants

content.text: Grants usually fund one-of initiatives perceived as creating value for the community. Examples include product/protocol modules, code reviews, relevant research, bd/growth initiatives, and ecosystem support initiatives. When the grant amount or delivery duration is significant, proposals can include milestones and quantitative metrics on what constitutes successful delivery. When the initiative benefits multiple communities, disclosing other funding applications can serve as a positive social signal.
[Provide a brief overview of the project's goals and objectives for which the grant is being sought.]

pages.title: Governance

content.text: Sometimes a community needs to change its governance, e.g., migrating from  Governor Alpha to Governor Bravo. Typically these meta-governance proposals take the form of contract migrations, but they can also involve the creation of subgroup structures. Additionally, they can involve
off-chain governance structures, such as moving governance forums, adopting off-chain voting methods, etc.

posts.title: Get the conversation started!

content.text: It is easy to start a conversation here, in CharmVerse! Simply click
from the dropdown menu. Make sure to title your post because you won't be able to publish it without one.
When creating a post, you have access to most of the CharmEditor's cool features.
text to style, format, or add a link
to bring up a menu of available blocks. Insert an image or video, embed a tweet or NFT, and more.
-mention a member, role, or even a page to add a useful link
It is also easy to join a conversation! Reply or add your thoughts below a post. The
comments will be threaded and easy to follow. And if you think a post is really amazing, don't forget to upvote

posts.contentText: 👋 Welcome to your CharmVerse Forum!It is easy to start a conversation here, in CharmVerse! Simply click [Create Post] and choose a Category from the dropdown menu. Make sure to title your post because you won't be able to publish it without one.When creating a post, you have access to most of the CharmEditor's cool features.Highlight text to style, format, or add a linkType / to bring up a menu of available blocks. Insert an image or video, embed a tweet or NFT, and more.@-mention a member, role, or even a page to add a useful linkIt is also easy to join a conversation! Reply or add your thoughts below a post. The 💬 comments will be threaded and easy to follow. And if you think a post is really amazing, don't forget to upvote ⬆️ .
